titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr: Hillhouse’s Section respecting the admission of slaves into Louisiana, was adopted— I called on Mr: J. C. Smith, chairman of the Committee of claims; and conversed with him in relation to that of Dr: Morse; and concerning the case of the brig Henrick— On the Louisiana Government Bill, Mr: Anderson moved to strike out the 8th: Section, which directed the Government of the second Territory— Debated untill 4. o’clock, and the question not taken— In the evening I continued Raynal’s Book 13.— Called yesterday and visited Judge Cushing.

2. Went to Georgetown to Mr: Caldwell’s Office, to ask for Copies of papers, Head and Amory vs the Providence Insurance Company— But he was not there— The debate on Mr: Anderson’s motion was continued this day in Senate untill 4. o’clock— The 8th: Section Struck out; yeas 16. nays 9.— In the evening, I finished reading to the Ladies, Julius Caesar.

3. Called at Mr: Caldwell’s Office in Georgetown again for the papers I wanted yesterday; but he was not at home.— In Senate The debate on Mr: Anderson’s motion was renewed, and General Jackson proposed by way of substitute that the Government of upper Louisiana should be annexed to the Indiana Territory, the question was not finally taken; but will doubtless finally prevail— Adjourned till Monday.— In the evening we were at a Ball given by Mr: T. Peter—on the Marriage of Mr: Caldwell— I play’d Chess with Mr: Madison— Saw Mr: Custis there—

4. Went to the Bank— Mrs: Hellen and Mrs: Adams paid visits to Judge Cushing’s Lady, and Mrs: Cranch. I called again on Mr: Caldwell and obtained the papers in the case of Head and Amory, vs Providence Insurance Company.— Called also upon Mr: Mason to engage him in the cause, and had some conversation with him— In the evening I examined and studied the papers. Dr: Rogers here.

5. Attended Church at the Capitol— An Episcopalian Clergyman, a Mr: Addison preach’d— His Sermon was peculiarly pointed against the writings of infidelity, circulating in this Country— The President
was there— It was a well timed, and spirited discourse— Captain Tingey, and his lady and daughter, and Mr: and Mrs: Duvall paid us visits— In the evening, I was employed upon the papers, of the law business, coming on for trial.

6. This day the Supreme Court of the United States was to have met— But only three Judges (Marshall, Cushing and Chase) appearing they adjourn’d the Court untill to-morrow, 12 o’clock— Mr: Graves called upon me. I went with him to Stelle’s where I found Messrs: Martin and Stockton— In Senate, the case of the brig Henrick was taken up, quite unexpectedly; but finally postponed without a decision— In the evening, I continued the examination of papers.— Genl: Sumpter took his seat.

7. Supreme Court sat, Judge Washington having arrived— I was admitted and sworn as Attorney and Counsellor in the Court— They did little business and adjourned early— In Senate— The Louisiana Government bill still debating. Section about the qualification of Jurors— Wrote to W. Morton. Deeply engaged all the evening, in examining Miller, Park and Powell— Mr: Nicholas gave notice that in order to make the Senate more punctual he should to-morrow at 11. o’clock move for a call of the House.

8. Attended at the Supreme Court and in the Senate— Examining authorities with perhaps too much assiduity— Part of the family dined at Mr: Pichon’s; but I was so deeply engaged in my inquiries that I could not go— Mrs: Adams went in the Evening— Mr: Hellen very unwell.

9. Supreme Court and Senate— In the latter the Convention of boundaries with Great-Britain, signed 12. May last, was ratified with the exception of the fifth Article— I moved to take off the injunction of secrecy— Motion to lie for consideration— In the evening still engaged as for some time past; and very late.— Letters from Mr: M. L. Davis—and W. A. Barron with a petition to Congress.— Mr: Wright also gave me the petitions of Coll: J. H. Stone, and Elijah Brainard— Committed to us & Mr: Armstrong.

10. A Short time at the Supreme Court; Mr: Dallas arguing a Cause— In Senate— Finished the Louisiana Government bill as in Committee of the whole, and it was reported to the Senate— Mr: Anderson prepared a new Amendment which was discuss’d and rejected.— In the evening our family, went to Dr: Thornton’s; but I was still engaged writing so that I could not go. They came home late.

11. Going up to the Capitol I met Mr: Boylston who was coming to see me. He has been to Quebec. And goes for Boston again next Tuesday. He returned with me to the Capitol.— Attended at the Supreme Court. Heard Mr: Harper, and Mr: Ingersoll on the question of the sugar refiners. Pass’d part of the day in the Library, consulting Books— Evening at home writing.
12. Spent the day at home, writing all the morning— Mr: Boylston dined with us— Visit from Mr: Harper— Evening, continued writing— On the case of Head and Amory with the Providence Insurance Company.

13. Met Mr: Boylston as I went up to the Capitol— Went with him to the Register’s Office— He goes away to-morrow morning— Debated on the Louisiana Government-Bill— It pass’d to the third reading by a small majority— Our Ladies spent the Evening at Mr. Deakins’s— I was still confined at home— This attendance on the Senate and the Supreme Court at once almost overpowers me. I cannot stand it long.

14. Debated the bill in the case of the Brig Henrick at the second reading— It was thrown out by a large majority.— A bill came from the house of Representatives for reducing the marine corps, which was also thrown out at the first reading— Evening at home; the Ladies spent it at Mr: Tayloe’s.

15. Louisiana Government bill at the third reading.— I was only part of the morning in Senate. The remainder of it attending upon the Supreme Court— Read the papers in the Case of Head and Amory— The Court are to hear the argument to-morrow— Evening at home— Publication in the National Intelligencer this morning.

16. Called this morning and left a paper to be published to-morrow morning in the Washington Federalist.— Attended at the Supreme Court, and argued the Cause of Head and Amory vs the Providence Insurance Company.— I was about two hours— Mr: Hunter and Mr: Martin then argued the case for the Defendants in Error— The Court seems to incline towards them— Mr: Mason is to close to-morrow for us. In Senate they were engaged again in the Louisiana bill— Evening at home.

17. The notice was published in the Federalist of this morning.— Attended a short time in Senate, and the remainder of the morning at the Supreme Court— Mr: Mason closed for us the cause of Head & Amory vs the Providence Insurance Company— And made an excellent argument— The Cause however will turn against us— The next case that came on is that of Graves vs the Boston Marine Insurance Company; which Mr: Stockton opened by a very able argument— On the whole I never have witness’d a collection of such powerful legal orators, as at this Session of the Supreme Court.— The Louisiana Government bill, proceeded to the question at its third reading; but the question was not taken— Evening at home.

18. Attended a short time at the Supreme Court; but I was called away to the question upon the Louisiana Government Bill— I spoke against it—alone— And was very shortly answered by Mr: Wright—alone. On the question the yeas were 20. the nays 5. Messrs: Dayton, Pickering, Tracy, Wells and White absent— Mr: Stone alone of the Major party voted against the bill— And thus terminates the introductory system for the Government of Louisiana— I have thought it placed upon wrong foundations— It is for Time to shew the result— Evening at home.

19. Heard Mr: Parkinson at the Capitol— Fine weather, and Spring approaching— The river broke up two days ago. Call’d and visited Mr: Van Rensselaer and Mr: Harper— They were both gone out— Return’d also Mr: Moses Young’s visit— He lodges at Stelle’s. At home the remainder of the day— Read Raynal Book 14. containing the History of the British islands in the West Indies.

20. Dr: Logan gave notice on Saturday, that he should this day move for leave to bring in a bill for laying a duty, on the importation of negro-slaves into the United-States.— This morning Mr: Tracy this morning moved to expunge from the Journals the record of this notice. It being a bill to raise Revenue, which therefore cannot by the Constitution originate in the Senate— It was amusing to observe the perplexity which this occasioned. Some were for expunging on the principle, that notice of an intention to bring in a bill, ought not in any case to be inserted in the Journals.— Others bravely stood to it, that it would not be a bill to raise revenue. Among whom was Dr: Logan himself— Who said he would shew it, when the bill came to be debated— This I suppose will be ad Calendas Graeces. On the question for expunging, the Doctor called for the yeas and nays— It pass’d in the negative yeas 5. nays 21.— But the Dr: did not ask leave according to his motion, and I think will find it most expedient to let it sleep.— I was in Court great part of the morning. Evening at home— Second publication in the National Intelligencer.

21. Called this morning at the Office of the Washington Federalist, and left an Advertisement to be published to-morrow morning— No person has applied for the name, offered in the Notice of last Week. Attended in the Senate— Several bills pass’d, almost without debate— An Act for the relief of Samuel Corp was debated, but no question taken— The Supreme Court did not sit, this day, Judge Chase being ill. Dined at Mr: Duvall’s— Judge Cushing & his Lady, Mr: & Mrs: Huger, and several other persons, were there— In the Evening there was other Company.— Home about 9 o’clock.

22. The advertisement appeared in the Washington Federalist, this morning— Attended a few minutes at the Senate, and all the rest of the Morning at the Supreme Court— The Chief Justice read the opinion of the Court in the case of Pennington and Cox— The famous case of the Sugar-refiners; and also in the case of the charming Betsey— In the former they reversed the decree of the Circuit Court. Mr: Mason opened a case of Insurance— The question is upon the degree of credit given to the sentence of a foreign Court of Admiralty.— Mr: Stockton also read the papers in the case of Church & Hubbart; and will open the Cause to-morrow— Dined at Stelle’s, in company with about 70 Gentlemen; in celebration of Washington’s birth-day— The Company consisted of Members of Congress, the Judges of the Supreme Court; and Gentlemen belonging to the City and neighbourhood— I came home early. The Ladies went to a Ball at Georgetown, for the same occasion— I pass’d the Evening at home, reading the papers in the case of Church & Hubbart.

23. Winter return’d severely— Snow all the morning, and very cold— Mr: Stockton opened the case of Church vs Hubbart, at the Supreme Court— He goes away to-morrow; and therefore the cause is to be finished at some future day— Mr: Hunter opened the defence upon the case of Fitzsimmons vs Newport Insurance Company— He was two hours on the point of credit due to a foreign Admiralty Sentence; after which the Court adjourn’d: he is to continue to-morrow— I scarcely attended in Senate— But nothing of material importance was done— Evening till midnight examining the papers in the case of Church and Hubbart.

24. Attended in Court—the Cause of Fitzsimmons and the Newport Insurance Company was this day finished, on the argument— In Senate little business done; and that of Executive nature— This evening the family spent at Mr: J. T. Mason’s— A Ball— I did not go, being engaged in business, untill past midnight— Weather very cold.

25. The Court delivered this morning an opinion in the case of Head and Amory, vs the Providence Insurance Company— Judgment of the Circuit Court reversed; unanimously— The Senate, having little business to do, adjourned early. I wrote letters to Mr: Amory, and to my brother— Dined at Mr: Nourse’s—with several Ladies and Gentlemen— We were late, and found them at dinner— Evening at home: reading Bacon, on Evidence.

26. I was not very well; and excepting a visit to Mr: Merry, to introduce General Wadsworth and Mr: Cutler, who called upon me for that purpose, I was the whole day at home; very assiduously writing, from early in the morning, untill late in the Evening.

27. I attended in Senate. The Seamen bill, was taken up, and debated at the second reading.— Several alterations were made, and it is to be printed over again, and taken up to-morrow. I was employed, all the morning, and untill late at night in writing, at home.

28. Wrote all the morning, and attended in Senate later than usual— The Seaman bill again taken up— Mr: Nicholas moved to postpone the consideration of it, to the first Monday, in December next. This was debated untill the adjournment— Finished my written argument for the case of Church and Hubbart— Made also a summary of its contents. up very late.

29. Debate in Senate continued this day— Seamen Bill postponed to the next Session. yeas 21. nays 11. While in debate, I was called out to attend the Supreme Court— Began the argument in the case of Church and Hubbart— About one hour— Court then adjourned— In the evening I reviewed the whole subject of the remainder of my argument, untill very late at Night.

Day.— The General course of daily occupation, as the preceding months— But I have been more constantly, and assiduously engaged, owing to the Session of the Supreme Court and necessary attendance upon it— This has obliged me to decline many invitations in the Evening; and more the once led me far beyond the hour of midnight, in my researches— This however is now at an end; my business with the Court being on the point of closing.
